I am pleased to announce that "Japanese Swords in Dutch Collections," the
2=
003 publication of the late Mr. Han Bing Siong by the Netherlands Token
Soc=
iety, is now in stock.

Though I have over the years read and admired Mr. H=
an's articles in the
JSS/US Newsletter, English Token Bijitsu, and elsewher=
e, spending some time
with this book has overwhelmed me with the extent of =
his scholarship and the
magnitude of our loss with his recent passing. 

As=
 the former owner of a katana signed (gimei, of course!) Hankei, I read
wit=
h interest the first entry in the book, a wakizashi by Hankei. I felt
like =
I learned more from that two pages than I had in all the reading I had
done=
 back when I owned that blade and dug up every article, oshigata, and
refer=
ence to Hankei that I could find. 

This is the kind of book that makes me =
proud to be a bookseller.


SIONG, HAN BING. Japanese Swords in Dutch Colle=
ctions A Selection from 500
Descriptions in the Series Japanse Zwaarden in =
Nederland Bezit. Rijswijk,
Netherlands: The Netherlands Token Society, 2003=
. First edition. 244 p.
Translated from the Dutch by J. M. Bonsel and M. La=
ros. This selection of
85 blades of the 500 cataloged by Han Bing Song sinc=
e 1979 was published to
celebrate the 25th anniversary of the Netherlands T=
oken Society. The
cataloging project included swords in museums as well as =
private
collections. Of those presented in this book, a range of swords fro=
m Koto
through Gendaito are shown with oshigata and Mr. Han's scholarly and=

insightful comments.  Seventeen of the blades are also presented in
photog=
raphs, and there are 14 pages of full color photographs of the best of
the =
koshirae. An outstanding publication of the highest quality and most
valuab=
le content. Pictorial Hardcover. As New.  	$100.00
